template_info.description: Question template for AI generation or manual creation
template_info.instructions: Replace the example questions with your own content. Ensure all required fields are present.

questions.question: Which TWO criteria must BOTH be true for information to be relevant in decision making?
options: It is about past costs and is the same across alternatives
It is an expected future cost or revenue AND it differs among alternatives
It is precise and audited
It is qualitative only
questions.correct_answer: It is an expected future cost or revenue AND it differs among alternatives
questions.explanation: Relevance requires futurity and differences between alternatives; past costs that don't change are irrelevant.

questions.question: Relevant information is the predicted {blank} that will differ among the alternatives.
options: future costs and revenues
future revenues and costs
questions.explanation: Only future costs/revenues that change between options are relevant.

questions.question: Which statement about sunk costs is TRUE?
options: They are past costs that cannot be changed and should be ignored in decisions
They are future costs that differ among alternatives
They represent opportunity costs of capacity
They are always variable
questions.correct_answer: They are past costs that cannot be changed and should be ignored in decisions
questions.explanation: Sunk costs are historical and unavoidable; they do not differ among alternatives.

questions.question: In the car purchase example, the $12,000 originally paid two years ago is a {blank} cost and should be ignored in the current decision.
options: sunk
sunk cost
questions.explanation: The purchase price is historical and cannot be changed by any current choice.

questions.question: Opportunity cost is best defined as:
options: The historical cost recorded in the accounting system
The potential benefit foregone by choosing one alternative over another
A future outlay of cash required by a chosen option
A cost that does not vary with activity
questions.correct_answer: The potential benefit foregone by choosing one alternative over another
questions.explanation: It's the value of the next-best alternative you give up.

questions.question: If you could earn $20,000 by working instead of attending college, your opportunity cost of attending college is {blank}.
questions.explanation: The foregone earnings represent the opportunity cost.

questions.question: You can fly to Las Vegas for $300 or take a bus for $50. What is the differential cost of flying?
Costs that differ between alternatives are called {blank} costs.
options: differential
incremental
questions.explanation: Differential (incremental) costs change depending on the option chosen.

questions.question: Which of the following is an avoidable cost?
options: Supervisor salary for a product line that will be dropped and not reassigned
Factory rent under a long-term noncancelable lease
Depreciation on equipment already owned with no alternative use
Allocated corporate headquarters salaries
questions.correct_answer: Supervisor salary for a product line that will be dropped and not reassigned
questions.explanation: If the salary will not continue when the product line is eliminated, it is avoidable and relevant.

questions.question: Costs that will not continue if an operation is discontinued are {blank} costs.
options: avoidable
avoidable costs
questions.explanation: Avoidable = can be eliminated by choosing an alternative.

questions.question: Match the cost hierarchy level with the change that eliminates it: Which level is avoided by eliminating one unit of product?
options: Batch-level
Product-level
Unit-level
Facility-level
questions.explanation: Unit-level activities scale with individual units; removing a unit avoids its unit-level costs.

questions.question: In a make-or-buy (outsourcing) decision, which cost comparison is appropriate?
options: Total manufacturing cost (including unavoidable) vs. purchase price
Avoidable internal manufacturing costs (including opportunity costs) vs. purchase price
Historical cost of equipment vs. purchase price
Allocated fixed overhead vs. supplier setup fee only
questions.correct_answer: Avoidable internal manufacturing costs (including opportunity costs) vs. purchase price
questions.explanation: Exclude unavoidable internal costs; include opportunity costs when comparing to the buy price.

questions.question: When evaluating make vs. buy, {blank} internal costs should be excluded from the analysis.
options: unavoidable
unavoidable costs
questions.explanation: Only costs that will change with the decision (avoidable) are relevant.

questions.question: When a single resource (e.g., machine hours) limits output across products, managers should typically:
options: Maximize total sales revenue regardless of cost
Maximize contribution margin per unit of the constrained resource
Allocate the constraint equally across products
Focus on reducing fixed costs first
questions.correct_answer: Maximize contribution margin per unit of the constrained resource
questions.explanation: With a binding constraint and fixed costs unaffected, choose the mix that maximizes CM per constrained resource.
